laboratory_examinations.findings: Cortisol levels on the first day of life: 526 nmol/liter (RR: 50–550); subsequently elevated cortisol of 2690 nmol/liter (RR: 50–550), and ACTH level: 1400 ng/liter (RR: 10–50). After seven consecutive evenings of treatment with 12 mg, cortisol was 2060 nmol/liter and ACTH was 2600 ng/liter.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Initial elevated cortisol of 526 nmol/liter increased to 2690 nmol/liter. ACTH levels increased from 1400 ng/liter initially to 2600 ng/liter after dexamethasone treatment.

laboratory_examinations.findings: 11-Deoxycortisol: 78 nmol/liter (RR: 125); Androstenedione: 52 nmol/liter (RR: 14); 17-Hydroxyprogesterone: 9.6 nmol/liter (RR: 17); Testosterone: 5.8 nmol/liter (RR: 4–12); Aldosterone: 1542 pmol/liter (RR: 50–5800); Renin level completely suppressed.
Peak GH level: 1.1 g/liter, consistent with GH deficiency.
Cortisol and ACTH levels did not suppress with doses of up to 12 mg dexamethasone.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: There was no suppression of cortisol and ACTH levels despite prolonged dexamethasone treatment.
